quoteTime: about four o’clock in the afternoon
quoteLast: , and at once began our exploration of the surrounding cliffs and the neighboring glacier, which Mr. Peary considered one of the first magnitude, and named, after the distinguished secretary of the American Geographical Society, the Hurlbut Glacier.
title: My Arctic journal: a year among ice-fields and Eskimos
author: Peary, Josephine Diebitsch, 1863-1955; Peary, Robert E. (Robert Edwin), 1856-1920 [Contributor]

quoteFirst: I ascertained the direction of the right one, got a boat, and crossing the deceptive stream, made across country to the boats, which we hit upon without difficulty; and without further adventure or mishap, but in dull and prosperous monotony, we punted our way to Islamabad, where we arrived
quoteTime: about 4 P.M.
quoteLast: , and after some delay, procuring coolies, I was safely lodged in the 'baraduri' which Willis and I occupied last autumn.
title: The Diary of a Hunter from the Punjab to the Karakorum Mountains
author: Irby, Augustus Henry

quoteTime: about 4 in the afternoon
quoteLast: when Granby and his English came into the fire; and I rather think the French onslaught was, if anything, more furious than ever:--Despair striding visibly forward on it, or something too like Despair. Amoneburg they had battered to pieces, Wall and Schloss, so that the 500 had to ground arms: but not an inch of way had they made upon the Bridge, nor were like to make.
title: History of Friedrich II of Prussia — Volume 20
author: Carlyle, Thomas, 1795-1881

quoteFirst: Under a standing rule, the twelve hundred prisoners were counted twice each day, the first count being made about nine in the morning, and the last
quoteTime: about four in the afternoon
quoteLast: . This duty was habitually done by the clerk of the prison, E.W. Ross, a civilian employed by the commandant. He was christened "Little Ross"[13] by the prisoners, because of his diminutive size.
title: Famous Adventures and Prison Escapes of the Civil War
author: Cable, George Washington, 1844-1925 [Editor]; Duke, Basil Wilson, 1838-1916; Hines, Thomas Henry, 1838-1898; Moran, Frank E., -1892; Pittenger, William, 1840-1904; Richards, A. E. quoteFirst: Stoneman pushed forward with cavalry and artillery, on a bold reconnoissance toward the rebel capital. Gen. Davidson’s Brigade followed, as a support, the rest of the Division remaining behind.
quoteTime: About four o’clock in the afternoon
quoteLast: , the General fell in with the enemy—“Howell Cobb’s Brigade”—who retreated after a few shots had been exchanged. Stoneman again moved forward, halting for the night just east of Beaver Dam Creek, and the Brigade, crossing over, took up position on an elevated spot, and slept on their arms.
title:
The story of the Thirty-Third N. Y. S. Vols
or two years campaigning in Virginia and Maryland
author: Judd, David Wright, 1838-1888

quoteFirst: Warren had made a mistake in Frederic’s last letter, the young man writing he should be home on the 15th, whereas she had read it the 17th; afterward, Frederic had decided to leave Riverside one day earlier, and he telegraphed from Cincinnati for Phil to meet him. Finding neither carriage nor servant in waiting, he hired a conveyance, and
quoteTime: about four o’clock P. M.
quoteLast: from every cabin door there came the joyful cry—
title: Marian Grey
author: Holmes, Mary Jane, 1825-1907

quoteTime: About four o’clock in the afternoon
quoteLast: , it was my daily habit to stroll down to the shore and hail Mat Barnes, who would presently paddle over in his skiff, and take me out to the boom for my afternoon swim. The boom was a most convenient and delightful place ‘to go in off of,’ as the boys say.
title: Around the Camp-fire
author: Roberts, Charles G. D., Sir, 1860-1943; Copeland, Charles, 1858-1929 [Illustrator]

quoteTime: About four o'clock in the afternoon
quoteLast: the carpenter came aft with the sounding-rod of the well in his hand.  The strain had been too much for her; some of the weakened timbers had given way, or some of the seams had opened, or perhaps a butt had started, for the ship was leaking badly.  Still those dauntless men did not despair.
title: For Love of Country: A Story of Land and Sea in the Days of the Revolution
author: Brady, Cyrus Townsend, 1861-1920

quoteTime: about four o'clock in the afternoon
quoteLast: . I had gone up on the little top-gallant-forecastle to have a look at the _Mercedes_ ground-tackle, when I made out, about two points on the bow, and less than a mile away, a ship's boat filled with men. They had discovered the bark, for they were pulling to get in her path.
title: Harper's Round Table, September 17, 1895
author: Various

quoteFirst: Later on, a second invitation will arrive, couched in the same terms; and again another on the day of the banquet, asking you to be punctual to the minute. To this you pay no attention, but make preparations to arrive
quoteTime: about 4 P.M.
quoteLast: , previous to which another and more urgent summons may very possibly have been sent. All this is conventional, and the guests assemble at the same hour, to separate about 9 P.M.
title: China and the Chinese
author: Giles, Herbert Allen, 1845-1935

quoteTime: about 4 P.M.
quoteLast: , the Prussian batteries awaken again: volcanic torrent of red-hot shot and shells, for seven hours; still no word from Roth. About 11 at night his Majesty again sends a Drum (Parley Trumpet or whatever it is) to the Gate; formally summons Roth; asks him, 'If he has well considered what this can lead to? Especially what he, Roth, meant by firing on our first Trumpet on Wednesday last?' Roth answered, 'That as to the Trumpet, he had not heard of it before.
title: History of Friedrich II of Prussia — Volume 12
author: Carlyle, Thomas, 1795-1881

quoteLast: there was nothing to be done except loaf around wishing for a breeze, and then the wind sprang up again in the same direction as before.

quoteFirst: The 8-inch guns of the naval brigade were the chief instruments in this formidable cannonade. At length,
quoteTime: about four o’clock in the afternoon
quoteLast: , Napier announced that the breaches were practicable, and Lugard at once made arrangements for storming the Begum Kothee. He had with him the 93d Highlanders, the 4th Punjaub Rifles, and 1000 Goorkhas, and was aided in the assault by Adrian Hope.
title: The History of the Indian Revolt and of the Expeditions to Persia, China and Japan, 1856-7-8

quoteFirst: At length we decided the best we could do was to lie between the edge of a wood and a barley field, a most exposed position if anyone should come that way. Soon we had no chance of changing our position if we would, as women at a very early hour began to work in the field within 100 yards of us.
quoteTime: About 4 o'clock in the afternoon
quoteLast: we heard a movement in the woods behind us. We had rigged up a sort of screen of boughs on that side, but we could scarcely hope that anyone would pass without seeing us if they came close.
title: The Escaping Club
author: Evans, A. J. (Alfred John), 1889-

quoteFirst: Now I must go back and tell you what was happening to the _Unity_ in all this while.
quoteTime: About four in the afternoon
quoteLast: Cap'n Dick, not liking the look of the weather at all, and knowing that, so long as it lasted, he might whistle for prizes, changed his mind and determined to run back to Polperro, so as to re-ship Cap'n Jacka and the prize crew almost as soon as they arrived.
title: The Laird's Luck and Other Fireside Tales
author: Quiller-Couch, Arthur, 1863-1944

quoteFirst: "Well, now, she did give me a beautiful welcome when I got there," continued Mrs. Hand.  "'T was
quoteTime: about four o'clock in the afternoon
quoteLast: , an' I told her I 'd come to accept her invitation if 't was convenient, an' the doctor had been called several miles beyond and expected to be detained, but he was goin' to pick me up as he returned about seven; 't was very kind of him.
title: The Queen's Twin and Other Stories
author: Jewett, Sarah Orne, 1849-1909

quoteFirst: , a circumstance occurred to break the uniformity of our existence, as according to the charts we were using of the Hydrographic Institute of England for the year 1856,[197] we must have been quite close to some coral reefs, known as Simpson's Island. But although by our observations, after due allowance made for currents, we were,
quoteTime: about 4 P.M.
quoteLast: of the 5th October, off the N.W. extremity of the islands, there was no land of any sort visible on either side even from the royals, and we accordingly had to conjecture that Captain Simpson, after whom these islands were named, must have sighted one of the Le Maire or Tasman group, which lie 40 miles further to the west and 10 miles further to the north, and had, owing to false reckoning, imagined to have discovered a new cluster; for on the following day at 6 P.M., when by our course, which was south-easterly, the island ought to have lain W.N.W.
title:
Narrative of the Circumnavigation of the Globe by the Austrian Frigate Novara, Volume II
(Commodore B. Von Wullerstorf-Urbair,) Undertaken by Order of the Imperial Government in the Years 1857, 1858, & 1859, Under the Immediate Auspices of His I. and R. Highness the Archduke Ferdinand Maximilian, Commander-In-Chief of the
Austrian Navy.
author: Scherzer, Karl, Ritter von, 1821-1903

quoteTime: About four o'clock in the afternoon
quoteLast: our animals were getting tired, and we ourselves were rather fatigued, having been in the saddle since daylight, with the exception of a few minutes' rest at Tierrabona. We halted at a thatched cottage on some high stony savannah land, and were hospitably received by the peasant proprietor, Don Filiberto Trano.
title: The Naturalist in Nicaragua
author: Belt, Thomas, 1832-1878
